Relevant macros / enum constants: LFS_TYPE_REG, LFS_F_INLINE, LFS_OK_DROPPED, LFS_OK_RELOCATED, LFS_OK_ORPHANED, LFS_ERR_NOENT, LFS_MKATTRS/LFS_MKTAG_IF/LFS_MKTAG (definitions)
explanation: To decide whether pointers in lfs_dir_orphaningcommit should be const-qualified we must know which objects are (a) modified inside the function and (b) potentially modified or required mutable by callees. For that we need: - Complete definitions of the involved types (lfs_t, lfs_file_t, lfs_mdir_t, lfs_mlist, lfs_dir_t, lfs_gstate_t, lfs_cfg, struct lfs_mattr, lfs_block_t) so we can see which members the function reads/writes (e.g. lfs->mlist, f->next, f->m, dir->pair, dir->tail, lfs->root, d->m, ((lfs_dir_t*)d)->head). If a pointed-to object is written here then the pointer cannot be const. - Prototypes (signatures) of all callees that receive pointers used here (lfs_pair_cmp, lfs_file_outline, lfs_file_flush, lfs_dir_relocatingcommit, lfs_dir_getgstate, lfs_pair_tole32, lfs_pair_fromle32, lfs_fs_parent, lfs_fs_preporphans, lfs_gstate_hasmovehere, lfs_tag_id, lfs_fs_prepmove, lfs_fs_pred, lfs_gstate_hasorphans). Their parameter const-qualifiers and whether they modify pointees determine whether the pointers passed from this function must be non-const. - Definitions of the used macros/enums and error/status constants (LFS_TYPE_REG, LFS_F_INLINE, LFS_OK_*, LFS_ERR_NOENT, LFS_MKATTRS/MKTAG macros) to understand control flow that conditions writes. In short: the type definitions show what this function itself mutates; the callee prototypes show whether passing a pointer requires mutability; the macros/constants show when those mutations occur. Without these symbols you cannot reliably determine if any pointer could be made const under MISRA C rule guidance.
